Caption: Fig. 1: a) A sample starting comparison from the experiment: r = 0.7 on the left and r = 0.6 on the right. Participants were asked to choose which of the two appeared to be more highly correlated. b) The staircase procedure hones in on the just-noticeable difference by gradually making comparisons more difﬁcult: r = 0.7 on the left and r = 0.65 on the right.

Fig. 2: Experiment 1 replicated the results from [22] on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, validating the platform for our larger experiment. (a) shows the raw data from previous studies [22]. (b) shows the raw data in Experiment 1. (c) shows the data after adjustment, where JNDs are drawn as functions of adjusted correlation rA . (d) compares previous regression results [22] and the regression from Experiment 1.

Fig. 3: The nine visualizations tested in our experiment, at several correlation values. Because many of these visualizations appear differently when depicting negatively versus positively correlated data, we test both in our experiment. The visualizations were larger (300×300 pixels) when presented to participants. The color scheme used is colorblind-safe, chosen from ColorBrewer.

Fig. 4: JND plotted as a function of correlation r for both above (light points) and below (dark points) approaches. Error bars show the standard- error of the mean (SEM). Broken lines show the chance and ceiling boundaries deﬁned in Section 3.2. The x-axis is correlation value r, the y-axis is JND.
Fig. 5: Regression results for several paired comparisons. JNDs are modeled as functions of adjusted correlation rA . The x-axis is adjusted correlation value rA , the y-axis is JND.
Table 2: Intercepts, Slopes, Correlation Coefﬁcients r, r2 , and RMS for JNDs modeled as functions of adjusted correlation rA .
Table 2: Intercepts, Slopes, Correlation Coefﬁcients r, r2 , and RMS for JNDs modeled as functions of adjusted correlation rA .

Fig. 7: Using the inferred Weber models, we can produce a perceptually-driven ranking for individual correlation (r) values, as well as an overall ranking (right column). Performance is ordered from the best (top) to the worst (bottom). The columns denoted by * are predicted responses using the ﬁt models shown in Figure 6.
